In this work, a series of hafnium-aluminum bimetallic oxide (Al-HfOx) catalysts were synthesized with the coprecipitation method, possessing outstanding catalytic effect in the conversion of glucose or fructose to 5-HMF. 5-HMF yield of 49.31% was acquired from glucose in a methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK)/saturated salt water (SSW) biphasic solvent at 170 ℃ after 2 h. When fructose was the substrate, 5-HMF yield was 74.85% in DMSO at 150 ℃ after 75 min. In addition, the reaction mechanism was speculated that the isomerization process could be promoted by the synergistic effects of aluminum and hafnium species, in which Hf-OH and Al-OH groups, and Hf active sites served as Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites, respectively. After at least four cycles, there was no remarkable wastage in the catalytic activity of Al-HfOx. This paper offers a prospective catalytic strategy for heterogeneous bimetallic oxide catalysts used in the effective conversion of carbohydrates to 5-HMF. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural Glucose Bimetallic oxide Mechanism Synergism Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The supply for fossil resources has been unable to meet the growing demand with the rapid development of economy [1]. It is extremely promising to develop and utilize renewable and pollution-free biomass resources to create a range of platform compounds and fuels, in order to reduce the dependence on fossil energy [2,3]. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF), one of the most significant, promising and widely used platform compounds transformed from biomass [4,5], can generate hundreds of different chemical compounds through dehydration, esterification, reduction, oxidation, decarbonylation and halogenation [6], which can be widely used in the synthesis of pharmaceutical intermediates [7], synthetic plastics [8], new polymer materials and diesel fuel additives [9,10]. However, due to the underwhelming performance of the catalytic system and the low 5-HMF yield, the industrial production of 5-HMF is constrained; consequently, exploiting a green and efficient catalytic system to enhance the synthesis of 5-HMF has become a research focus [11]. The commonly used catalysts to convert carbohydrates to 5-HMF can be categorized as homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts [12]. Among them, homogeneous catalysts have many weaknesses such as corrosiveness and difficult recovery [13], including metal chlorides, ionic liquids, organic and inorganic acids [14]. There are more advantages for heterogeneous catalysts than homogeneous catalysts, such as easier control of morphology, higher stability, and easy separation [15]. Metal oxides as a very significant kind of heterogeneous catalysts were studied for the production of 5-HMF from various carbohydrates [16,17]. The composite metal oxide catalysts such as CeO2-Nb2O5, WO3/SnO2, WO3-TiO2, ZrO2-SnO2 have been synthesized and used for the conversion of carbohydrate [18-21]. Wherein the catalyst WO3-TiO2 applied for the dehydration of glucose to synthesize 5-HMF, the highest yield of 58% with glucose conversion of 90% could be acquired. It was found that these composite metal oxide catalysts not only showed fantastic catalytic activity for the conversion of carbohydrates, but also kept their activity basically unchanged and had good stability in multiple cycles. According to previous reports, metal Hf as Lewis acid sites can effectively promote the isomerization of glucose [22]. For example, Wu et al. reported that Hf-ZSM-5 catalyst was used to catalyze the preparation of 5-HMF from cellulose [23], Qiu et al. reported that Sn-HfO2 composite metal oxides catalyzed the conversion of 5-HMF from dextrose [24], and Hu et al. demonstrated that Hf-MOF catalyzed the preparation of 5-HMF from fructose [25], which showed that hafnium could be employed as an active metal to convert carbohydrate into 5-HMF; the study on the transformation of glucose to 5-HMF catalyzed by Al(OMe)3 catalyst published by Wang et al. [26], the study on the conversion of 5-HMF from glucose catalyzed by aluminum oxide reported by Hou et al. [27], and the study on the synthesis of 5-HMF from cellulose catalyzed by Al/SBA-15 reported by Pham et al. [28], indicated that aluminum, as an active metal, could be employed to transfer carbohydrates to 5-HMF. However, the exploration on the preparation of carbohydrates to 5-HMF catalyzed by Al-Hf bimetallic oxides have not been reported. In this study, a series of novel composite hafnium-aluminum oxide (Al-HfOx) catalysts having various Al/Hf molar ratios were synthesized by the coprecipitation method, and possessed exceptional performance in the synthesis of 5-HMF with fructose or glucose. The catalytic activity of composite Al-HfOx and the optimal reaction conditions were investigated, and it was found that the isomerization process could be aided by the synergistic impact of aluminum and hafnium species. Furthermore, the recoverability of Al-HfOx and its catalytic role in converting other carbohydrates were also studied, while the reaction mechanism of Al-HfOx catalyst catalyzed the transformation of glucose to 5-HMF was also further discussed. The study provided a novel strategy to further design an effective catalytic system in transforming renewable biomass to platform chemical 5-HMF. 2 Experimental Section 2.1. Experimental reagents and instruments D-glucose (99%), D-fructose (99%), sucrose (99.9%), D-cellobiose (98%), hafnium oxide (99.5%), anhydrous aluminum chloride (99%), dimethyl sulfoxide (>99.9%) and N, N-dimethylacetamide (≥99.8%) were bought from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd; Mannose (AR) and methanol (99.9%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. D-maltose (97.0%), methyl isobutyl ketone (99.0%), N, N-dimethylformamide (99.5%) and N-methylpyrrolidone (≥99.5%) were obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd; Hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (99%), sodium hydroxide (≥98.0%) and sodium chloride (≥99.5%) were purchased from Shanghai Titan Scientific Co., Ltd. All reagents need not be further purified before using. X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Ultima IV of Japanese Neo Confucianism) with the scanning angle from 3° to 90° was used to identify the crystal framework of samples. The composition and chemical bonding state of Al-HfOx were studied by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer (TENSOR 27, Bruker) using a 400 to 4000 cm−1 wavelength range. With X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), the surface elemental structure and valence state analysis of Al-HfOx samples were performed, and the XPS data were recorded by Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument. The binding energy value was calibrate based on the peak value of C 1s (284.6 eV). X-ray fluorescence analysis (XRF) (PANalytical-Axios) was used for qualitative and quantitative analysis of elements in different Al-HfOx samples. By using a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area meter (Cantor AUTOSORB IQ), the pore diameters and specific surface area of Al-HfOx samples were determined. Hitachi U4150 spectrophotometer was used to conduct Ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflection spectrum (UV-vis DRS) analysis to calculate the absorption value of the sample and examine the Al and Hf species composition. The element distribution and morphology of Al-HfOx catalyst were inspected by EDS mapping (HV=200 kV) and FEI Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscope (TEM). By using pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy, the types of acid sites on Al-HfOx were identified, then the data were stored on the FTIR spectrometer. Flake Al-HfOx samples were prepared by pressing the powder, and the acid strength of the samples was measured by NH3-temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). 2.2. Catalyst preparation In a regular preparation, a certain number of aluminum chloride and hafnium tetrachloride were completely dissolved in 25 mL of deionized water and stirred with magnetic stirrer for 2 h. 0.5 g of CTAB was weighed and dissolved in 10 mL deionized water by ultrasonic vibration, and slowly dropped into the mixed salt solution of hafnium tetrachloride and aluminum chloride. The well-mixed solution was prepared and further stirred for 2 h. A certain amount of ammonia was contributed gradually into the stirred mixture and the pH was controlled to 9.8 to obtain milky white suspension. Then, the mixture was stirred for 2 h and transferred to a high-pressure reactor placed in an oven at 120 ℃ for 12 h. After the ageing process, the white solid obtained from reaction was collected through filtration, washed for three times with deionized water, and stuck in the oven for 12 h at 100 ℃. A portion of samples was put into a muffle furnace with temperature 500 ℃ roasting for 3 h. Through the aforementioned synthetic method, hafnium and aluminum oxides composite with various molar ratios of Al/Hf were prepared and named mAl-HfOx, where m signifies the molar ratio of Al to the total amount of metal in the catalyst. 2.3. General procedure for 5-HMF synthesis A given amount of catalyst, monosaccharide and solvent were added into a 15 mL pressure-resistant reaction tube placed in an oil bath at certain temperatures. The mixture was stirred with an internal magnetic stirrer at a speed of 500 rpm. After the reaction, the reaction tube was taken out and immediately cooled, then a 0.45 μm filter membrane was used for solid-liquid separation. The filtrate was layered and diluted with methanol or ultrapure water for product analysis. The concentration of monosaccharide and 5-HMF were determined by external standard method. After the reaction, the reaction diluent was analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), in order to further pinpoint the concentration of associated reactants and products in combination with the standard curve. The 5-HMF concentration was calibrated by HPLC (Waters e2695) equipped with UV detector and C18 column (250 mm×4.6 mm), using the acetonitrile/water mixture (10/90 v/v; flow rate of 1 mL/min) as mobile phase. The concentration of monosaccharide could be calibrated by HPLC (Waters e2695) equipped with RI detector and inertsil NH2 column (250 mm×4.6 mm), using the acetonitrile/water mixture (75/25 v/v; flow rate of 1 mL/min) as mobile phase and setting the column temperature at 35 ℃. 3 Results and Discussions 3.1. Characterization of Al-HfOx catalysts The FTIR spectra of Al-HfOx catalysts are displayed in Fig. 1 (a). The two bands at 520 cm−1 and 760 cm−1 were corresponding to Hf-O stretching vibration when Al content in the sample was low [29], indicating that hafnium oxide skeleton structure predominated in Al-HfOx. With the increasing of Al, it could be clearly observed that the relevant band intensity of Hf-O decreased gradually; Concurrently, a broadband at about 580 cm−1 has some slight enhancement in the intensity, according with the stretching vibration of O-Al-O and Al-O [30]. These findings supported that the skeleton structures of alumina and hafnium oxide coexist in Al-HfOx samples, which was consistent with the design. Fig. 1(b) showed the XRD results of Al-HfOx. The typical diffraction peaks corresponded to the structure of hafnium oxide were found at 24.3°, 28.4°, 31.6°, 34.5°, 35.4°, 38.8°, 41.1°, 45.4°, 50.4° and 55.8° (JCPDS Card No. 74-1506) [31], and the corresponding intensity of the above peaks subsequently decreased as the Al content increased. Simultaneously, it was observed that the peak intensity at 21.8°, 46.5° and 67.3° increased significantly, which were in accord with the skeleton of alumina (JCPDS Card No. 04-0877). These outcomes validated that hafnium oxide and aluminum oxide can be produced via coprecipitation synthesis. The high-resolution XPS spectrums of Al-HfOx catalyst are shown in Fig. 2 (a) and (b), further exploring the chemical states of Al and Hf. The Al spectrum had only one characteristic peak at 74.0 eV, which was consistent with Al 2p [32]. The spectrum of Hf 4f included two distinguishing peaks at 16.8 eV and 18.4 eV, respectively, representing Hf 4f7/2 and Hf 4f5/2 [33,34], which were characteristic peaks of tetravalent hafnium. TEM image and EDS mapping results (Fig. S1) showed the elements of Hf, Al and O distribution in Al-HfOx samples, XRF test results (Table 1 ) showed that the molar ratio of Al/Hf was basically identical to the designed value, demonstrating that Al ions were effectively incorporated into the skeleton structure of HfOx and there were no metal ions leaching throughout the preparation of Al-HfOx. The N2 adsorption-desorption results (Table 2 ) showed that the specific surface area of bimetallic oxides was much larger than that of monometallic oxides, but there is no regular change in pore volume. Fig. S2 showed UV-vis DRS spectra of 0.5Al-HfOx-500, 0.5Al-HfOx and HfOx-500 catalysts while the peak at 293 nm corresponds to tetravalent Hf, conclusively demonstrating the presence of Hf-O framework structure. There was only weak acid peak appeared in NH3-TPD results of the samples (Table 2 and Fig. S3), and the introduction of aluminum led a larger peak area and stronger acidity for Al-HfOx-500 catalysts, in which the acid strength had been further improved for 0.5Al-HfOx-500. The type of acid sites on 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalyst was determined by Infrared spectra of pyridine adsorption. The coordination of aluminum or hafnium ions with pyridine molecules was accomplished by the Lewis acid sites, which were corresponding to the powerful peaks at 1448 cm−1 and 1610 cm−1 as displayed in Fig. 3 . The weak peaks at around 1550 cm−1 belong to Brønsted acid sites, which were produced by protonating pyridine molecules adsorbed in the terminal Hf-OH and Al-OH groups [35]. The exceedingly weak Brønsted acidity was merely as a result of a small amount of terminal hydroxyl, that was primarily due to the solvent water adhering to the catalyst surface in the course of synthesis. In addition, the peaks at around1490 cm−1 mostly originated from the interactivity of pyridine molecules with Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [36]. As soon as the temperature reached 200 °C, the relevant peak intensity decreased marginally, which was related to the constancy of hydroxyl groups and metal ions in the sample. Hence, the results showed that 0.5Al-HfOx-500 sample possessed weak Brønsted and strong Lewis acid sites. 3.2. Catalytic activity of Al-HfOx on the conversion of glucose and fructose (Reaction conditions: 66.7 mM of substrate, 20 mg of catalyst, a and b1.5 mL SSW-3.5 mL MIBK, 160 ℃, 3 h; c 5 mL DMSO, 150 ℃, 1 h) Fig. 4 (a) and (b) showed the results of preparing 5-HMF from glucose catalyzed by a series of as-synthesized and 500 ℃-calcined Al-HfOx catalysts. In overall comparison, the calcined Al-HfOx possessed better effect which might be due to the preferable thermal stability and more exposing acidic surfaces [37,38]. Almost 30% yield of 5-HMF were gained with HfO2 or AlO2 as a catalyst, indicating that monometallic HfO2 and AlO2 had a noticeable promotion effect on glucose conversion, duo to the catalysis of active site Hf for the transformation of carbohydrate [24]. The catalytic effect of the non-calcined bimetallic catalyst added with metal aluminum decreased relatively might due to non-calcined process leading to a weaker bonding effect, thus a decreasing in 5-HMF yield. After calcination, the catalytic performance was significantly improved, possibly due to the stronger binding of two metals after calcination, making the acidity stronger, thereby further improving the 5-HMF yield. In addition, it can be observed that 0.5Al-HfOx-500 had the maximum catalytic activity among the catalysts synthesized, possibly due to the intervention of a certain amount of metal aluminum helping to enhance the surface acidity of monometallic oxide HfOx catalyst and the synergistic effect of metal Hf and Al. However, adding excessive aluminum metal might cover the Hf site [39], leading to a reduction in the contact area between the active site of the catalyst and the substrate, then reducing the 5-HMF yield. When the molar ratio of Al to metal was 0.5, the distribution of active centers on the catalyst surface was the most uniform, and the total acid content is the highest, so the production of 5-HMF from glucose catalyzed by 0.5Al-HfOx-500 obtained maximum yield. Similarly, Fig. 4(c) showed the results of preparing 5-HMF with fructose as the substrate catalyzed by a series of 500 ℃-calcined Al-HfOx. It was evident that the catalytic effect of the 0.5Al-HfOx was optimum with fructose used as the substrate, achieving the highest 5-HMF yield of 73.98% at 150 ℃ for 1 h. Table S1 summarized the reported results of catalysts catalyzing the conversion of glucose or fructose to 5-HMF, further confirming the excellent catalytic effect of 0.5Al-HfOx-500. Since 0.5Al-HfOx catalyzed fructose and glucose to 5-HMF obtaining the maximum 5-HMF yield, the following experiments were conducted with 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalyst. 3.3. Determination of optimal reaction conditions for 0.5Al-HfOx-500-catalyzed conversion to 5-HMF (Reaction conditions: (a) 66.7 mM of fructose, 20 mg of 0.5Al-HfOx-500, 5 mL of DMSO; (b) 66.7 mM of glucose, 20 mg of 0.5Al-HfOx-500, 1.5 mL SSW-3.5 mL MIBK) Fig. 5 showed the extremely significant effects of temperature on 5-HMF yield with fructose and glucose used as the substrates. In the initial stage of the reaction, the yield of 5-HMF improved gradually with the extension of time, and the higher initial rate of reaction could be obtained with higher temperature, thus the shorter time was required to reach the optimal yield at higher temperature. However, it should be noted that the optimal yield of 5-HMF did not necessarily be the highest with higher temperature. It could be clearly seen from Fig. 5(a) that the maximum 5-HMF yield of 74.85% was obtained from fructose at the temperature of 150 ℃ after 75 min. Afterwards, 5-HMF yield slightly decreased with the reaction time increasing, due to the polycondensation of the substrate and the partial disintegration of 5-HMF, leading to the formation of by-products like the humins, formic acid, and levulinic acid [40]. Fig. S4 showed the result of fructose conversion changing with reaction temperatures, displaying that fructose conversion rate increased with the raising temperature. The higher the reaction temperature was, the faster the conversion rate was during the reaction. And a maximum conversion reached 100% at the different temperatures after 80 min, indicating that the catalytic effect of Al-HfOx-500 was excellent. Fig. 5(b) showed 5-HMF yields changing with temperatures with glucose used as substrate, whose trend was similar to that of fructose, but the influence of temperature was more significant for glucose converting. The highest 5-HMF yield of 47.07% was acquired from glucose at 170 ℃ after 120 min. Fig. S5 presented the conversion rate of glucose, and the changing trend was also consistent with that of fructose, however glucose was not fully converted until 120 min when the temperature was relatively low. Therefore, with fructose and glucose as reaction substrates, the most appropriate reaction temperatures were 150 ℃ and 170 ℃, respectively. (Reaction conditions: (a) 66.7 mM of fructose, 5 mL of DMSO, 150 ℃, 75 min; (b) 66.7 mM of glucose, 1.5 mL SSW-3.5 mL MIBK, 170 ℃, 120 min) The effect of the dose of 0.5Al-HfOx-500 on 5-HMF yield obtained from fructose and glucose is shown in Fig. 6 . In the absence of 0.5Al-HfOx-500, fructose could be converted into 5-HMF in DMSO solution with a certain yield, which was due to trace amounts of acid generated from DMSO promoting the dehydration reaction, and the coordination of DMSO as a polar coordinating solvent that made the produced 5-HMF poorly accessible to water molecules, thus exerting stabilization effect and inhibiting the hydration of 5-HMF. However, it was much lower than the yield in the presence of catalyst 0.5Al-HfOx-500. Meanwhile, the yield of glucose conversion to 5-HMF in biphasic solvent without the catalyst 0.5Al-HfOx-500 was extremely low. Obviously, when the dose of 0.5Al-HfOx-500 was raised from 10 mg to 20 mg, the transforming rates were greatly accelerated from fructose, and the influence was more significant for the conversion of glucose, since the fact that Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on the 0.5Al-HfOx catalyst surface could effectively promote the dehydration of fructose and isomerization of glucose [41], thus promoting the formation of 5-HMF from monosaccharide. However, as the 0.5Al-HfOx-500 dosage reached 100 mg, the addition of 0.5Al-HfOx-500 brought about a gradual reduction in 5-HMF yield, as result of the massive overdose of 0.5Al-HfOx-500 leading to the decomposition of 5-HMF and occurrence of side reactions. Therefore, 20 mg was chosen as the optimal amount of 0.5Al-HfOx-500 for higher 5-HMF yields. (Reaction conditions: (a) 20 mg of 0.5Al-HfOx-500, 5 mL of DMSO, 150 ℃, 75 min; (b) 20 mg of 0.5Al-HfOx-500, 1.5 mL SSW-3.5 mL MIBK, 170 ℃, 120 min) Under the conditions of optimal reaction temperature, the influence of primary substrate density on 5-HMF yield was further studied as displayed in Fig. 7 (a) and Fig. 7(b), and 5-HMF yields from fructose and glucose had similar changing trend. When the substrate concentration was raised from 33.3 mM to 66.7 mM, the 5-HMF yield with fructose and glucose were obviously increased to 74.85% and 47.07%, respectively. Because the sufficient diffusion could accelerate the movement of chemical equilibrium to 5-HMF during the lower-concentrations substrate conversion [42]. However, continuously increasing the initial concentration to 166.7 mM could lead to a gradual decline in 5-HMF yield when fructose and glucose were used as the substrates, which might be due to that excessive sugar molecules could reduce the contact with acidic sites, further leading to the appearance of polymerization and the occurrence of humins, that was not conducive to the reaction [43]. Interestingly, even with a higher substrate concentration, the yield of 5-HMF with fructose or glucose as the substrate could be not less than 60% and 40%, respectively; indicating that 0.5Al-HfOx-500 possessed good catalytic activity in glucose and fructose converting to 5-HMF with higher concentration. 3.4. Catalytic effect of 0.5Al-HfOx in different solvents on the synthesis of 5-HMF (Reaction conditions: (a) 66.7 mM of fructose, 20 mg of 0.5 Al-HfOx-500, 5 mL of solvent, 150 ℃, 75 min; (b) 66.7 mM of glucose, 20 mg of 0.5 Al-HfOx-500, 5 mL of solvent, 170 ℃, 120 min) The impact of solvents on 5-HMF yield was also very significant, and several commonly used solvents were further investigated to explore the solvent effect, involving water, saturated salt water (SSW), methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK), N, N-dimethyl formamide (DMF), N, N-dimethyl acetamide (DMA), N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). Fig. 8 (a) showed the experimental results obtained from the 5-HMF synthesis with fructose as the substrate in various solvents, suggesting that the yield of 5-HMF was maximum when DMSO was used as the solvent, reaching 74.85%, which was due to the coordination of DMSO as a polar coordinating solvent that made the produced 5-HMF poorly accessible to water molecules, thus exerting stabilization effect and inhibiting the hydration of 5-HMF [44]. There were lower than 35% yields of 5-HMF gained in the organic solvents such as NMP, DMA and MIBK, while almost no 5-HMF was produced with DMF used as the solvent. Although fructose was easily soluble in water, 5-HMF yield was not high with water as a solvent, due to the fact that water as the reaction medium promoted further hydration of 5-HMF resulting in the formation of additional by-products [45]. Compared with water, 5-HMF yield was slightly increased with SSW as the solvent, because the salting out effect of chloride ions from SSW increased the reaction rate and thus the 5-HMF yield [46]. As displayed in Fig. 8(b), the results obtained from the production of 5-HMF with glucose as substrate, investigated the effects of seven kinds of single-phase solvents as well as different ratios of biphasic solvents (MIBK-SSW) on 5-HMF yield. In comparison, the optimal results were achieved from SSW among the single-phase solvents, followed by water, NMP, and DMF with essentially no yield in MIBK and DMA, which might be due to low solubility of glucose in DMA and MIBK or the generation of humins [47]. The 5-HMF yield was 21% when using water as a solvent, indicating that 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalyst possessed excellent catalytic activity and water resistance, thus preventing the side reaction in the synthesis of 5-HMF. Among the biphasic solvents (MIBK-SSW) with different ratios, the maximum 5-HMF yield of 49.31% was acquired in the optimum volume ratio (80 : 20) of MIBK and SSW solvent. It was obvious that the yield of 5-HMF in 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalytic system in two-phase solvent is much higher than that in single-phase solvent, so MIBK-SSW (80 : 20) as the biphasic solvent was selected in glucose dehydration. 3.5. The catalytic conversion of different carbohydrates to 5-HMF with 0.5Al-HfOx-500 (Reaction conditions: (a) 66.7 mM of substrate, 20 mg of 0.5Al-HfOx-500, 5 mL of solvent, 170 ℃, 120 min; (b) 35 mM of substrate, 20 mg of 0.5Al-HfOx-500, 5 mL of solvent, 170 ℃, 120 min) Based on the effective conversion of glucose, different substrates catalyzed with 0.5Al-HfOx-500 were further studied in two-phase solvent SSW-MIBK and single-phase solvent DMSO, as shown in Table 3 . It was worth noting that in the SSW-MIBK two-phase solvent, the 5-HMF yield was more than 36% with different carbohydrates used as substrates, proving that the feasibility of 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalyst in the two-phase solvent. And the yield of 5-HMF in SSW phase was lower than that in MIBK phase, which was mainly ascribed to that the organic solvent has stronger extraction ability for 5-HMF, avoiding the occurrence of dehydration. Specifically, the highest 5-HMF yield reaching 47.07% in biphasic solvent was obtained with glucose as the substrate, that is because biphasic solvents could promote the effect of reaction-storage space separation [48]. The inferior yield of 5-HMF with glucose was gained because glucose reacting vigorously with 0.5Al-HfOx-500 in DMSO leading to the presence of side-reactions [49]. The utmost 5-HMF yield in DMSO solvent was 41.90% with sucrose as the substrate, indicating 0.5Al-HfOx-500 played a significant role during the initial hydrolysis. Therefore, the difficulties in the hydrolysis and dehydration of polysaccharides have gained proper settlements, and 0.5Al-HfOx-500 was versatile and effective for catalyzing the production of different carbohydrates to 5-HMF. 3.6. Catalyst recyclability (Reaction conditions: 66.7 mM of fructose, 20 mg of 0.5Al-HfOx-500, 5 mL of DMSO, 150 ℃, 10 min) Fig. 9 displayed the results of recovering and reusing 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalyst in order to assess its recyclability. After the reaction, the 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalyst was filtered, collected and washed with the deionized water for three times and finally the collected samples are dried at 100 ℃ overnight [50]. After four recycling experiments, fructose conversion rate and 5-HMF yield were 77.12% and 44.91% respectively, slightly lower than those in the primary reaction. Fig. S7 showed the reusability of 0.5Al-HfOx-500 used in glucose conversion, and the results were very similar to that of fructose, which probably because the presence of trace by-products on the active site of 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalyst or the micro amount leaching of Al and Hf during the cycle, which has been confirmed through thermal filtration experiments (Fig. S6). Hence, the 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalyst can be efficiently separated and recycled in 5-HMF synthesis. The infrared spectrum of 0.5Al-HfOx-500 after four cycles was shown in Fig. S8 and there was no distinct difference in the characteristic peaks between the original and reused catalyst. The high-resolution XPS spectrum (Fig. S9) of the recycled 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalyst showed that the valence of Al and Hf had not changed significantly, and the pyridine adsorption infrared spectrum (Fig. S10) presented that Brønsted and Lewis acidity of the recycled catalysts only slightly decreased, indicating that the functional group and framework structure remains unchanged after four cycles, proving that 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalyst possessed high stability and recycling performance. 3.7. Speculation of the catalytic mechanism In combination with previous experimental results, the likely catalytic mechanism of Al-HfOx for the conversion from glucose to 5-HMF was speculated, as shown in Scheme 1 . Through the coordination between O1 and Lewis acid Hf site, the hydrogen proton was transferred to adjacent surface Al-O species, leading to deprotonation of O1H (1-2-3-4). By obtaining hydrogen protons from adjacent Al-O-H species in the surface, the protonation of pyranose O5 site resulted in ring-opening and the formation of aldehyde group (4-5-6) at O1 site. Then the hydrogen proton was shifted from O2 site to Al-O through the alteration of O1@Hf and O2@Hf coordination mode, causing O2H to be deprotonated and the rebirth of hydroxyl groups on terminal Al-OH (6-7-8). The subsequent process involved an intramolecular proton transfer from C2 to C1, which results in the formation of five element chelate structure bringing about the transition from aldehyde O1- to carbonyl O2-residue and aldose-ketose isomerization (8-9-10). This was the conformation change from a bidentate coordination chelate to a monodentate midbody along with the open chain modality of O1-deprotonated fructose attached to the mononuclear Hf site forming. Subsequently, the relocation of hydrogen proton from O5 site to O2 aldehyde residue promoted the closed-loop procedure and produced O1 deprotonated cyclic fructose (10-11-12). The proton was transferred from Al-O to ultimate O1 site that accelerated the formation of isomerization product D-fructofuranose and restored the initial structure of Al-HfOx concurrently (12-13-14-15). To demonstrate the above steps, high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was used to detect the reaction solution of glucose in the initial stage of the reaction, the presence of fructose was clearly captured at 170 ℃ for 5 min (Fig. S11). Thus, the isomerization from glucose to fructose was successfully completed, consequently the three-step dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF catalyzed by Al-HfOx. At the edge of Al-HfOx, the water molecules that were absorbed generated a little amount of terminal hydroxyl during the synthesis of Al-HfOx catalyst, which was the major reason of extremely weak Brønsted acidity of Al-HfOx. Under the action of hydrogen bond, Hf-OH attacked C2-OH bond of fructose to produce the first water molecule, generating an aldehyde group on the branch chain (16-17-18). Meanwhile, C3-OH and C4-OH bond were respectively stuck by the hydrogen protons of Al-OH and Hf-OH to form a furan ring and two water molecules, which obtained the end-product 5-HMF and restored the framework of Al-HfOx (18-19-20). This was the another synergistic impact of Hf and Al active sites accelerating the synthesis speed, while weak Brønsted acid sites on Al-HfOx catalyst; in other words, the three-step dehydration of fructose could be successfully facilitated by Hf-OH and Al-OH groups under the influence of hydrogen bond. 4 Conclusions This study explores the feasibility and optimal reaction conditions of multiphase bimetallic oxides as vaild catalysts to synthesize 5-HMF from glucose and fructose. The utmost 5-HMF yields of 49.31% and 74.85% were obtained from the transformation of glucose in biphasic solvent and fructose in DMSO with 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalyst, respectively. After four cycles, it has been proving that the 0.5Al-HfOx-500 catalyst not only can be efficiently separated and recycled in 5-HMF synthesis, but also has the excellent stability efficient catalytic performance. A prospective reaction mechanism of the conversion from glucose and fructose to 5-HMF was provided, wherein the Hf-OH and Al-OH groups could successfully facilitate the isomerization process of glucose to fructose and the three-step dehydration of fructose under the influence of hydrogen bond. Therefore, these findings offer a green and valid measure for the preparation of 5-HMF with carbohydrates, and the metal oxide catalysts synthesized in this paper have significant practical application. coredata.dc:description: 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) is considered as a bridge connecting biomass and petrochemical products with excellent application potential and market prospects. In this work, a series of hafnium-aluminum bimetallic oxide (Al-HfOx) catalysts were synthesized with the coprecipitation method, possessing outstanding catalytic effect in the conversion of glucose or fructose to 5-HMF. 5-HMF yield of 49.31% was acquired from glucose in a methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK)/saturated salt water (SSW) biphasic solvent at 170 ℃ after 2 h. When fructose was the substrate, 5-HMF yield was 74.85% in DMSO at 150 ℃ after 75 min. In addition, the reaction mechanism was speculated that the isomerization process could be promoted by the synergistic effects of aluminum and hafnium species, in which Hf-OH and Al-OH groups, and Hf active sites served as Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites, respectively. After at least four cycles, there was no remarkable wastage in the catalytic activity of Al-HfOx. This paper offers a prospective catalytic strategy for heterogeneous bimetallic oxide catalysts used in the effective conversion of carbohydrates to 5-HMF.
coredata.dc:title: Effective Synergistic Hafnium-Aluminum Bimetallic Oxides catalysts for the Synthesis of 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural from Glucose and Fructose
